posts.cooked:
We are going to be documenting our offseason build progress here. We created this blog in order to get out there with the first community.

We made it to Worlds for the first time in team history and our epa graph actually has an upward trend.

image 2145×1036 82.1 KB

image 2145×1036 82.1 KB

image 2145×1036 82.1 KB

image 2134×667 46.5 KB

image 2134×667 46.5 KB

image 2134×667 46.5 KB

Thank you to our mentors/parents, sponsors, and students who made this possible. Special Thanks to our friends 1325 and 9785 for graciously letting us use their fields. And our alliance partners, 8884, 919, 9785, 9562, 9525, 5024. Thank you to those who inspired us to write a build blog, all of OA , and especially 4481 & 7285/9483. Mandatory worlds recap video drop:

Enough yap here is the build blog:

Compete at the Robots@CNE and Stemley Cup/Overtime Sunday Offseason events.

Get next years students more familiar with robot designing and programming

Build more complex/better machines so we can become more competitive in the future

Alongside that, we will be attempting to upgrade our main season robot.

image 1920×1280 290 KB The changes haven’t been discussed yet but we plan on adding a deep climb.

image 1920×1280 290 KB

image 1920×1280 290 KB

image 991×935 67.7 KB

image 991×935 67.7 KB

image 991×935 67.7 KB

The current robot is ~95% done in CAD, minor additions are needed to the intake/indexer, electronics like cameras, and some extra support for the climber. The design is based off of 4414 and 1690 who we got to play with and against this season.

image 814×808 122 KB

image 814×808 122 KB

image 814×808 122 KB

Continuous Rope Driven Elevator

Powered by 2 Krakenx44’s with either 4:1 or 5:1 (TBD)

Stabilized with tie rods

SDS Bearing Blocks

image 942×867 117 KB

image 942×867 117 KB

image 942×867 117 KB

Pivot driven by a kraken x60, 2 maxplanetary stages to a 4:1 gear reduction, 10dp gears to avoid skipping

Kraken geared 12:1 for end effector wheels to grab both algae and coral

Carbon Fiber Box Tube, in tube belt for hand rollers

LaserCAN on the end for easy CANbus integration

image 1077×663 92.6 KB

image 1077×663 92.6 KB

26x26 L2 MK4i’s (Fast Acceleration due to short cycles)

All Krakens with CTRE Swerve

Dropped by 1" to lower COG

Cameras mounted on swerve covers

Powered by 2 Kraken x44’s

125:1 Neo

Slapdown Intake

Lots of star wheels

Floating Roller so coral can be intaked from all orientations

Pivot: 2 Neo Vortex’s 42:1, 1 on each side due to lack of space to run a jackshaft

Custon chain tensioner w/ zipties

Slightly Offset to fit with elevator

Kraken powered rollers

Thank you for reading and I hope to see you on our future posts. Please let us know if you have any questions.

Mandatory Social Links: TBA Instagram Youtube Team Website

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked: That looks amazing, and ambitious.  I look forward to seeing it at the CNE in a couple months.  Good luck completing it!

Hi! We are currently trying to restore our last years offseason robot Snapback. It was partly disassembled for some aggressive drive practice and the elusive kraken motors. Snapback was loosely based around 254’s omni-feeding pizza box idea. And was named after a song that came out on May 24, 2024. It competed at 2 events, Robots@CNE and Overtime Sunday captaining the 6th and 5th alliance respectively. (Frens: 7902, 2935B, 9062, 2852) We hope to get some more use out of it as we attend/host more outreach events.

Written by: @overclockedfyre -

Written by: @overclockedfyre -

Greetings! We are still working on many things. Albeit the new offseason robot progress is slow there are many things that we do.

We got our outreach robot all* fixed up and its ready to shoot notes at our misbehaving members again! (For legal reasons thats a joke)(Also the notes are very soft and do not hurt) *One of the pizza ring Falcon 500’s has very low torque (could be burnt up?) and has made the omni feeding very hard

Unfortunately, there will be no Robots@CNE this year, as a team we are grief-stricken.

But we are excited for Robots@ ! Thank you to the team there for all that they do to make this event happen.

We have finalized the BOM for the competition robot. Other than that no other updates, keeping our fingers crossed for when Kraken x44’s and x60’s to come back in stock soon so we can snag some for our robot.

By technicality, our team was 1 week behind schedule now that Robots@? has been pushed back we are 2 weeks ahead of schedule. Work slower and you’ll be rewarded with more time. But in all/half seriousness if we keep this pace up we will either be around 10 weeks behind schedule or 20+ weeks ahead of schedule.

Our competition season robot may undergo some changes and we discovered that it can do this:

Surely we can fit a deep climb there? We’ll have to see.

We have organized our shop. It used to look like a pigsty. (Imagine the same image but with 2 more tables and stuff everywhere)  Thank you to our parents for doing this. image 1226×919 139 KB image 1226×919 135 KB

image 1226×919 139 KB

image 1226×919 139 KB

image 1226×919 135 KB

image 1226×919 135 KB

Thank you for reading this, we know this doesn’t get seen much but we appreciate the community for being so welcoming.

Us during the CNE cancellation announcement not reading carefully:

Written by: @Overclockedfyre -

Written by: @Overclockedfyre -

Hi everyone! It has been a while since the last update, and we have made major advancements. So here are a few following things:

Our prototyping has started on the hand/arm subsystem. This is the current progress of our hand/arm:

We had a few issues with coral getting stuck when entering horizontally, however, we have fixed it with our recent revision. Here’s a video:

We have assembled all stages and found out our string isn’t long enough. Stay tuned for following updates, here’s a video in the meantime:

We blew up our climber… however we adjusted our string attachment method and it works now. Video of it working:

We have started our design on our bumpers and it is still a work in progress, we are deciding between 1, 2, and 4 piece bumpers and also different attachment methods. We mounted the swerve modules onto the base as well as the general frame. We are waiting for our baseplate to be cut to further our progress.

Overall, we have made significant progress on our offseason robot so far, and we hope to see you all at Robots at Mary Ward!

Written by: @Spoon2 -

Written by: @Spoon2 -
